case_name: C. A. Abraham v. Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 517 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 517 of 1958. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 31, 1957 of Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 215 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1957, of the Kerala High Court in O. P. No. 215 of 1957.

facts.text: C.A. Abraham and M.P. Thomas carried on business in food grains in partnership as M.P. Thomas Company at Kottayam.

anchor.surface_text: C. A. Abraham hereinafter referred to as the appellant and one M. P. Thomas carried on business in food grains in partnership in the name and style of M. P. Thomas Company at Kottayam.

facts.text: M.P. Thomas died on October 11, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: M. P. Thomas died on October 11, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant submitted returns of income of the firm as unregistered firm for account years 1123, 1124 and 1125 M.E. corresponding to August 1947-July 1948, August 1948-July 1949 and August 1949-July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: For the account years 1123, 1124 and 1125 M.E. companyresponding to August 1947-July 1948, August 1948-July 1949 and August 1949-July 1950, the appellant submitted as a partner returns of the income of the firm as an unregistered firm.

facts.text: Firm carried on transactions in different commodities in fictitious names and failed to disclose substantial income earned therein.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of the assessment proceedings, it was discovered that the firm had carried on transactions in different companymodities in fictitious names and had failed to disclose substantial income earned therein.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer by order dated November 29, 1954 assessed suppressed income of the firm for assessment year 1124 M.E. under Travancore Income Tax Act and for 1949-50 and 1950-51 under Indian Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 29, 1954, the Income Tax Officer assessed the suppressed income of the firm in respect of the assessment year 1124 M.E. under the Travancore Income Tax Act and in respect of assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 under the Indian Income Tax Act

facts.text: On November 29, 1954, Income Tax Officer issued notices under s.28 Indian Income Tax Act for 1949-50 and 1950-51 and under s.41 Travancore Income Tax Act for 1124 M.E. requiring firm to show cause why penalty should not be imposed.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day issued numberices under s. 28 of the Indian Income Tax Act in respect of the years 1949-50 and 1950-51 and under s. 41 of the Travancore Income Tax Act for the year 1124 M.E., requiring the firm to show cause why penalty should number be imposed.

facts.text: Notices served upon the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: These numberices were served upon the appellant.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer imposed penalty on firm of Rs. 5,000 for 1124 M.E., Rs. 2,000 for 1950-51 and Rs. 22,000 for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer after companysidering the explanation of the appellant imposed penalty upon the firm, of Rs. 5,000 in respect of the year 1124 M.-E., Rs. 2,O00 in respect of the year 1950-51 and Rs. 22,000 in respect of the year 1951-52.

facts.text: Appeals against orders of Income Tax Officer dismissed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals against the orders passed by the Income Tax Officer were dismissed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 215 of 1957 for writ of certiorari quashing assessment and penalty orders.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court of Judicature of Kerala praying for a writ of certiorari quashing the orders of assessment and imposition of penalty.

facts.text: Appellant claimed that after dissolution of firm by death of M.P. Thomas in October 1949, no order imposing penalty could be passed against the firm.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed by the appellant inter alia that after the dissolution of the firm by the death of M. P. Thomas in October, 1949, numberorder imposing a penalty companyld be passed against the firm.

facts.text: Kerala High Court rejected the application following judgment in Mareddi Krishna Reddy v. Income Tax Officer, Tenali.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the application following the judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Mareddi Krishna Reddy v. Income Tax Officer, Tenali  1 .

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with certificate of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order dismissing the petition, this appeal is preferred with certificate of the High Court.

facts.text: Business of the firm was discontinued because of dissolution of partnership, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: That the business of the firm was discontinued because of the dissolution of the partnership is number disputed.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer found appellant deliberately concealed material particulars of income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer found that the appellant had, with a view to evade payment of tax,  1   1957  31 I.T.R. 678. deliberately companycealed material particulars of his income.

facts.text: Firm made no entries in books for transactions in diverse names and made false credit entries of loans.

anchor.surface_text: Even though the firm was carrying on transactions in food grains in diverse names, numberentries in respect of those transactions in the books of account were posted and false credit entries of loans alleged to have been borrowed from several persons were made.

facts.text: Conditions under s.28(1)(c) for imposing penalty fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: The companyditions prescribed by s. 28 1  c  for imposing penalty were therefore fulfilled.

facts.text: Supreme Court held petition should not have been entertained as adequate remedy by appeal to Tribunal available.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the petition filed by the appellant should number have been entertained. The Income Tax Act provides a companyplete machinery for assessment of tax and imposition of penalty and for obtaining relief in respect of any improper orders passed by the Income Tax authorities,

facts.text: High Court entertained petition and granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court did entertain the petition and has also granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal on merits, holding penalty imposition valid post-dissolution under s.44.

anchor.surface_text: The expression assessment used therein does number merely mean companyputation of income. The expression assessment as has often been said is used in the Income Tax Act with different companynotations. In Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay Presidency Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas  1 , the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed One of the peculiarities of most Income-tax Acts is that the word assessment is used as meaning sometimes the companyputation of income, sometimes the determination of the amount of tax payable and sometimes the whole procedure laid down in the Act for imposing liability upon the tax-payer.

concepts.interpretation: Assessment includes not just computation of income but entire procedure for imposing liability, including penalties.

arguments.claim: s.44 ensures continuity of assessment machinery post-discontinuance, deeming firm to continue for Chapter IV purposes including penalties.

anchor.surface_text: In effect, the Legislature has enacted by s. 44 that the assessment proceedings may be companymenced and companytinued against a firm of which business is discontinued as if discontinuance has number taken place. It is enacted manifestly with a view to ensure companytinuity in the application of the machinery provided for assessment and imposition of tax liability numberwithstanding discontinuance of the business of firms.

arguments.claim: Narrow interpretation allowing evasion of penalty by dissolution not intended; comprehensive words in s.44 cover penalties.

anchor.surface_text: It is implicit in the companytention of the appellant that it is open to the partners of a firm guilty of companyduct exposing them to penalty under s. 28 to evade penalty by the simple expedient of discontinuing the firm. This plea may be accepted only if the companyrt is companypelled, in view of unambiguous language, to hold that such was the intention of the Legislature.

arguments.claim: View in Rayalaseema Oil Mills and S.V. Veerappan Chettiar incorrect; overruled Mareddi wrongly.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view expressed by the Andhra Pradesh High Court in the later Full Bench decision in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Rayalaseema Oil Mills  1 , which purported to overrule the judgment in Mareddi Krishna Reddys case  supra . We are also unable to agree with the view expressed by the Madras High Court in S. V. Veerappan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras  2 .

holdings.text: The petition under Article 226 should not have been entertained as the Income Tax Act provides complete machinery for assessment, penalty, and relief, with adequate remedy by appeal to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the petition filed by the appellant should not have been entertained. The Income Tax Act provides a complete machinery for assessment of tax and imposition of penalty and for obtaining relief in respect of any improper orders passed by the Income Tax authorities,

holdings.reasoning_summary: IT Act has complete statutory machinery; writ not permissible when alternative remedy exists.

holdings.text: Penalty under s.28(1)(c) can be imposed on a dissolved firm as partners are jointly and severally liable under s.44, which applies all Chapter IV provisions including penalties.

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 of the Act at the material time stood as follows Where any business,carried on by a firm has been discontinued every person who was at the time of such discontinuance a partner of such firm, shall in respect of the income, profits and gain of the firm be jointly and severally liable to assessment under Chapter IV for the amount of tax payable and all the provisions of Chapter IV shall, so far as may be, apply to any such assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.44 deems firm to continue for assessment under Chapter IV; no lacuna preventing penalty.

holdings.text: 'Assessment' under s.44 and Chapter IV includes the entire procedure for imposing tax liability, not merely computation of income, encompassing penalties under s.28.

anchor.surface_text: The expression assessment used therein does not merely mean computation of income. The expression assessment as has often been said is used in the Income Tax Act with different connotations. In Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay Presidency Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas 1 , the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed One of the peculiarities of most Income-tax Acts is that the word assessment is used as meaning sometimes the computation of income,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Privy Council in Khemchand Ramdas; Chapter IV covers computation, determination, and full procedure including penalties.

holdings.text: s.44 applies all provisions of Chapter IV, including s.28 penalties, to assessments of discontinued firms; no lacuna exists.

anchor.surface_text: liable to assessment under Chapter IV for the amount of tax payable and all the provisions of Chapter IV shall, so far as may be, apply to any such assessment. That the business of the firm was discontinued because of the dissolution of the partnership is not disputed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual application of 'all provisions of Chapter IV so far as may be'; ensures continuity for tax liability including penalties.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.25A for Hindu Undivided Families and s.44 for firms are not in pari materia; no analogy for penalty lacuna post-disruption.

anchor.surface_text: But whether on the dissolution of a Hindu Joint Family the liability for penalty under s. 28 which may be incurred during the subsistence of the family cannot be imposed does not fall for decision in this case it may be sufficient to observe that the provisions of s. 25A and s. 44 are not in pari materia.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.44 expressly applies all Ch.IV provisions, unlike s.25A.

holdings.text: Fiscal statutes must be interpreted as they stand; in doubt, favour taxpayer, but comprehensive words imposing penalty for fraud etc. not narrowly construed to create evasion loophole.

anchor.surface_text: In interpreting a fiscal statute, the court cannot proceed to make good deficiencies if there be any the court must interpret the statute as it stands and in case of doubt in a manner favourable to the tax-payer. But where as in the present case, by the use of words capable of comprehensive import, provision is made for imposing liability for penalty upon tax-payers guilty of fraud, gross negligence or contumacious conduct,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance strict construction with purposive reading to prevent evasion by dissolution.

holdings.text: Mareddi Krishna Reddy v. ITO correctly holds that s.28 applies to assessments under Chapter IV post-discontinuance via s.44.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, Chief Justice Subba Rao has correctly stated in Mareddi Krishna Reddys case supra that Section 28 is one of the sections in Chapter IV. It imposes a penalty for the concealment of income or the improper distribution of profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 facilitates proper assessment; part of Ch.IV process.

holdings.text: Views in CIT v. Rayalaseema Oil Mills and S.V. Veerappan Chettiar v. CIT incorrect; do not approve overruling of Mareddi Krishna Reddy.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view expressed by the Andhra Pradesh High Court in the later Full Bench decision in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Rayalaseema Oil Mills 1 , which purported to overrule the judgment in Mareddi Krishna Reddys case supra . We are also unable to agree with the view expressed by the Madras High Court in S. V. Veerappan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with s.44 interpretation and comprehensive assessment meaning.

anchor.surface_text: Mareddi Krishna Reddys case  supra  that Section 28 is one of the sections in Chapter IV. It imposes a penalty for the companycealment of income or the improper distribution of profits.

precedents.case_name: Mareddi Krishna Reddy v. Income Tax Officer, Tenali
precedents.cited_proposition: s.28 is part of Chapter IV machinery for assessment, applies post-discontinuance via s.44
precedents.cited_holding: Section 28 is one of the sections in Chapter IV. It imposes a penalty for the concealment of income... The defaults enumerated therein relate to the process of assessment. Section 28, therefore, is a provision enacted for facilitating the proper assessment of taxable income and can properly be said to apply to an assessment made under Chapter IV.

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 of the Act at the material time stood as follows Where any business,carried on by a firm has been discontinued every person who was at the time of such discontinuance a partner of such firm, shall in respect of the income, profits and gain of the firm be jointly and severally liable to assessment under Chapter IV for the amount of tax payable and all the provisions of Chapter IV shall, so far as may be, apply to any such assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The expression assessment used therein does not merely mean computation of income. anchor.surface_text: In interpreting a fiscal statute, the court cannot proceed to make good deficiencies if there be any the court must interpret the statute as it stands and in case of doubt in a manner favourable to the tax-payer. But where as in the present case, by the use of words capable of comprehensive import, provision is made for imposing liability for penalty upon tax-payers guilty of fraud, gross negligence or contumacious conduct,
